titlePage.docImprint: London : Printed by Isaac Iaggard, and Ed. Blount [at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley]., 1623.

foliation.p: Numbering peculiarities: 1st count: p.50 misnumbered 58; p.59 misnumbered 51; p.86 misnumbered 88; p.153 misnumbered 151; p.161 misnumbered] 163; p.164 misnumbered 162; p. 165 misnumbered 163; p. 189 misnumbered 187; p. 249 misnumbered 251; p.250 misnumbered 252; p. 265 misnumbered 273 -- 2nd count: p.37 misnumbered 39 in some copies; p.89 misnumbered 91; p. 90 misnumbered 92 -- 3rd count: p.165-166 numbered 167 and 168 respectively; p. 216 numbered 218 -- 5th count: p. 279 misnumbered 259; p. 282 misnumbered 280; p.308 misnumbered 38; p. 379 misnumbered 389; p. 399 misnumbered 993.

collation.p: The signatures varies between sources, with the most commonly cited being Hinman's and West's: 1. Hinman: œÄA‚Å∂ (œÄA1+1) [œÄB¬≤], ¬≤A-2B‚Å∂ 2C¬≤ a-g‚Å∂ œágg‚Å∏ h-v‚Å∂ x‚Å¥ œá1.2 [para.]-2[para.]‚Å∂ 3[para]¬π aa-ff‚Å∂ gg¬≤ Gg‚Å∂ hh‚Å∂ kk-bbb‚Å∂; 2. West: œÄA‚Å∂ (œÄA1+1, œÄA5+1.2)¬≤A-2B‚Å∂ 2C¬≤ a-g‚Å∂ ¬≤g‚Å∏ h-v‚Å∂ x‚Å¥ 'gg3.4' (¬±'gg3') [para.]-2[para.]‚Å∂ 3[para]¬π 2a-2f‚Å∂ 2g¬≤ 2G‚Å∂ 2h‚Å∂ 2k-2v‚Å∂ x‚Å∂ 2y-3b‚Å∂.
Mis-signed leaves: a3 mis-signed Aa3; ¬≥gg1 mis-signed Gg; nn1-nn2 mis-signed Nn and Nn2 and oo1 mis-signed Oo.
"The life and death of King Iohn" begins new pagination on leaf a1 recto; "The tragedy of Coriolanus" begins new pagination on leaf aa1 recto.

supportDesc.condition: Lacks A1, the letterpress frontispiece entitled "To the reader". The title page is trimmed and mounted, with a section of the mount towards the foot of the leaf mutilated resulting in the loss of some the Droechout imprint at the bottom left hand corner of the portrait and the central section of an early MS note. For a full condition report, including a full survey of damage and repairs, please contact Rare Books.

layout.p: Colophon reads: "Printed at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley. 1623.".
Editors‚Äô dedication signed: Iohn Heminge. Henry Condell.

decoDesc.decoNote: With an engraved title-page portrait of the author signed: "Martin- Droeshout: sculpsit¬∑ London.". The plate exists in 2 states: 1. The earlier state has lighter shading generall ; 2. Later state has heavier shading, especially around the collar, and minor differences particularly with the jawline and moustache. The vast majority of surviving copies have the plate in the second state which has led some scholars to conclude that the earlier state was a proof. The portrait in this copy is the second state.

additions.p: Two MS verses on first endpaper verso: 1. 9 lines of verse by an unknown author, first line reads "An active swain to make a leap was seen". 2. A copy of Ben Jonson‚Äôs printed "To the Reader"; MS note on t.p. (mutilated) appears to read "Honest [Shakes]peare". Minor annotations on leaf 2n4 (Macbeth). All in an early English hand, presumably added after leaving the Library.

bindingDesc.p: Seventeenth-century (1624) English (Oxford) smooth calf. Bound for the Bodleian Library by William Wildgoose, with evidence of two cloth ties, red sprinkled edge. Formerly chained, with evidence of chain staple at the head of the upper cover. Remains of paper label at the head of the spine. Enclosed in 20th century book box by Maltby of Oxford. See S. Gibson in Original Bodleian Copy of First Folio, p. 12-13. One of four items sent out on 17th February 1624 for binding by Wildgoose containing printed waste from a copy of Cicero‚Äôs "De Officiis, et al." [Deventer: Richard Pafraet, between 1480 and 1485] as paste-downs. For more information on this work see: Bod. Inc. Cat., C-322.

origin.p: For further details on the printing of this item see Hinman, Charleton. The printing and proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare: Oxford, 1963.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bodleian in 1623, presumably in sheets. It was sent out to William Wildgoose on 17 February 1624 for binding (see: Library Records e.258, fol. 48r) and upon its return chained in Duke Humfrey at shelfmark S 2.17 Art. It is listed in the Bodleian‚Äôs 1635 catalogue of printed books but was gone by the publication of the next catalogue in 1674, replaced by the newer Third Folio (1664). There is no explicit reference in Library Records to the disposal of this copy, but there is a record of a sale of "superfluous library books" to Richard Davis, a bookseller in Oxford, in 1664 for the sum of ¬£24.

After leaving the Bodleian this copy entered the collection of Richard Turbutt of Ogston Hall, Derbyshire at some point in the early 18th century. It stayed in the family‚Äôs possession until 1906, when it was reacquired by the Bodleian for the sum of ¬£3000, raised by public subscription. For a full discussion of the rediscovery and purchase of this copy see: F. Madan, G. M. R. Turbutt and S. Gibson, The Original Bodleian Copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare (theTurbutt Shakespeare) (Oxford, 1905)
For a full discussion of this copy and the digital version see http://shakespeare.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/ and West and Rasmussen (2011), 31.

person.persName: Antonio, a sea captain, friend to Sebastain
Feste, a clown, servant to Olivia
Curio, gentleman attending on the Duke
Sir Toby Belch, uncle to Olivia
Valentine, gentleman attending on the Duke

div.head: Twelfe Night, Or what you will.
Actus Primus, Sc√¶na Prima.
[Act 1, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Orsino Duke of Illyria, Curio, and other
Lords.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If Musicke be the food of Loue, play on,An ink mark follows the end of this line.
Giue me excesse of it: that surfetting,
The appetite may sicken, and so dye.
That straine agen, it had a dying fall:
O, it came ore my eare, like the sweet sound
That breathes vpon a banke of Violets;
Stealing, and giuing Odour. Enough, no more,
Tis not so sweet now, as it was before.
O spirit of Loue, how quicke and fresh art thou,
That notwithstanding thy capacitie,
Receiueth as the Sea. Nought enters there,
Of what validity, and pitch so ere,
But falles into abatement, and low price
Euen in a minute; so full of shapes is fancie,
That it alone, is high fantasticall.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Will you go hunt my Lord?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What Curio?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: The Hart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why so I do, the Noblest that I haue:
O when mine eyes did see Oliuia first,
Me thought she purg'd the ayre of pestilence;
That instant was I turn'd into a Hart,
And my desires like fell and crull hounds,
Ere since pursue me. How now what newes from her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So please my Lord, I might not be admitted,
But from her handmaid do returne this answer:
The Element it selfe, till seuen yeares heate,
Shall not behold her face at ample view:
But like a Cloystresse she will vailed walke,
And water once a day her Chamber round
With eye‚Äëoffending brine: all this to season
A brothers dead loue, which she would keepe fresh
And lasting, in her sad remembrance.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of loue but to a brother,
How will she loue, when the rich golden shaft
Hath kill'd the flocke of all affections else
That liue in her. When Liuer, Braine, and Heart,
These soueraigne thrones, are all supply'd and fill'd
Her sweete perfections with one selfe king:
Away before me, to sweet beds of Flowres,
Loue‚Äëthoughts lye rich, when canopy'd with bowres.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
[Act 1, Scene 2]
div.stage: Enter Viola, a Captaine, and Saylors.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What Country (Friends) is this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This is Illyria Ladie.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elizium,
Perchance he is not drown'd: What thinke you saylors?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It is perchance that you your selfe were saued.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: O my poore brother, and so perchance may he be.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: True Madam, and to comfort you with chance,
Assure your selfe, after our ship did split,
When you, and those poore number saued with you,
Hung on our driuing boate: I saw your brother
Most prouident in perill, binde himselfe,
(Courage and hope both teaching him the practise)
To a strong Maste, that liu'd vpon the sea:
Where like Orion on the Dolphines backe,
I saw him hold acquaintance with the waues,
So long as I could see.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: For saying so, there's Gold:
Mine owne escape vnfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy speech serues for authoritie
The like of him. Know'st thou this Countrey?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I Madam well, for I was bred and borne
Not three houres trauaile from this very place.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Who gouernes heere?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A noble Duke in nature, as in name.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Orsino.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Orsino: I haue heard my father name him.
He was a Batchellor then.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And so is now, or was so very late:
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then 'twas fresh in murmure (as you know
What great ones do, the lesse will prattle of,)
That he did seeke the loue of faire Oliuia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What's shee?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A vertuous maid, the daughter of a Count
That dide some tweluemonth since, then leauing her
In the protection of his sonne, her brother,
Who shortly also dide: for whose deere loue
(They say) she hath abiur'd the sight
And company of men.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: O that I seru'd that Lady,
And might not be deliuered to the world
sp.note: The corner of this page has been torn away, so no catchword is visible.

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Till I had made mine owne occasion mellow
What my estate is.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: That were hard to compasse,
Because she will admit no kinde of suite,
No, not the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: There is a faire behauiour in thee Captaine,
And though that nature, with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution: yet of thee
I will beleeue thou hast a minde that suites
With this thy faire and outward charracter.
I prethee (and Ile pay thee bounteously)
Conceale me what I am, and be my ayde,
For such disguise as haply shall become
The forme of my intent. Ile serue this Duke,
Thou shalt present me as an Eunuch to him,
It may be worth thy paines: for I can sing,
And speake to him in many sorts of Musicke,
That will allow me very worth his seruice.
What else may hap, to time I will commit,
Onely shape thou thy silence to my wit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Be you his Eunuch, and your Mute Ile bee,
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thanke thee: Lead me on.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What a plague meanes my Neece to take the
death of her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemie to
life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
By my troth sir Toby, you must come in earlyer
a nights: your Cosin, my Lady, takes great exceptions
to your ill houres.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Why let her except, before excepted.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
I, but you must confine your selfe within the
modest limits of order.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Confine? Ile confine my selfe no finer then I am:
these cloathes are good enough to drinke in, and so bee
these boots too: and they be not, let them hang them¬≠
selues in their owne straps.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
That quaffing and drinking will vndoe you: I
heard my Lady talke of it yesterday: and of a foolish
knight that you brought in one night here, to be hir woer

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Who, Sir Andrew Ague‚Äëcheeke?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I he.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What's that to th'purpose?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Why he ha's three thousand ducates a yeare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, but hee'l haue but a yeare in all these ducates:
He's a very foole, and a prodigall.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Fie, that you'l say so: he playes o'th Viol‚Äëde‚Äëgam¬≠
boys, and speaks three or four languages word for word
without booke, & hath all the good gifts of nature.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
He hath indeed, almost naturall: for besides that
he's a foole, he's a great quarreller: and but that hee hath
the gift of a Coward, to allay the gust he hath in quarrel¬≠
ling, 'tis thought among the prudent, he would quickely
haue the gift of a graue.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
By this hand they are scoundrels and substra¬≠
ctors that say so of him. Who are they?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
They that adde moreour, hee's drunke nightly
in your company.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: With drinking healths to my Neece: Ile drinke
sp.note: The corner of this page has been torn away, and the tears slightly obscure these last lines.
sp.p:
to her as long as there is a passage in my throat, & drinke
in Illyria: he's a Coward and a Coystrill that will not
drinke to my Neece. till his braines turne o'th toe, like
a parish top. What wench? Castiliano vulgo: for here coms
Sir Andrew Agueface.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Sir Toby Belch. How now sir Toby Belch?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sweet sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Blesse you faire Shrew.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And you too sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Accost Sir Andrew, accost.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: My Neeces Chamber‚Äëmaid.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Good Mistris accost, I desire better acquaintance

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: My name is Mary sir.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Good mistris Mary, accost.

sp.speaker: To,
sp.p:
You mistake knight: Accost, is front her, boord
her, woe her, assayle her.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
By my troth I would not vndertake her in this
company. Is that the meaning of Accost?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Far you well Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
And thou let part so Sir Andrew, would thou
mightst neuer draw sword agen.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
And you part so mistris, I would I might neuer
draw sword agen: Faire Lady, doe you thinke you haue
fooles in hand?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir, I haue not you by'th hand.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Marry but you shall haue, and heeres my hand.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Now sir, thought is free: I pray you bring your
hand to'th Buttry barre, and let it drinke.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Wherefore (sweet‚Äëheart?) What's your Meta¬≠
phor?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It's dry sir.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Why I thinke so: I am not such an asse, but I
can keepe my hand dry. But what's your iest?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A dry iest Sir.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Are you full of them?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
I Sir, I haue them at my fingers ends: marry now
I let go your hand, I am barren.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
O knight, thou lack'st a cup of Canarie: when did
I see thee so put downe?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Neuer in your life I thinke, vnlesse you see Ca¬≠
narie put me downe: mee thinkes sometimes I haue no
more wit then a Christian, or an ordinary man ha's: but I
am a great eater of beefe, and I beleeue that does harme
to my wit.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: No question

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
And I thought that, I'de forsweare it. Ile ride
home to morrow sir Toby.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Pur‚Äëquoy my deere knight?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
What is purquoy? Do, or not do? I would I had
bestowed that time in the tongues, that I haue in fencing
dancing, and beare‚Äëbayting: O had I but followed the
Arts.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of haire.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Why, would that haue mended my haire?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Past question, for thou seest it will not coole my
(nature

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But it becoms me wel enough, dost not?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Excellent, it hangs like flax on a distaffe: & I hope
to see a huswife take thee between her legs, & spin it off.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Faith Ile home to morrow sir Toby, your niece wil
not be seene, or if she be it's four to one, she'l none of me:
the Count himselfe here hard by, wooes her.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Shee'l none o'th Count, she'l not match aboue hir
degree, neither in estate, yeares, nor wit: I haue heard her
swear t. Tut there's life in't man.

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Ile stay a moneth longer. I am a fellow o'th
strangest minde i'th world: I delight in Maskes and Re¬≠
uels sometimes altogether.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Art thou good at these kicke‚Äëchawses Knight?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
As any man in Illyria, whatsoeuer he be, vnder
the degree of my betters, & yet I will not compare with
an old man.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Faith, I can cut a caper.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And I can cut the Mutton too't.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
And I thinke I haue the backe‚Äëtricke, simply as
strong as any man in Illyria.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore haue
these gifts a Curtaine before 'em? Are they like to take
dust, like mistris Mals picture? Why dost thou not goe
to Church in a Galliard, and come home in a Carranto?
My verie walke should be a Iigge: I would not so much
as make water but in a Sinke‚Äëa‚Äëpace: What dooest thou
meane? Is it a world to hide vertues in? I did thinke by
the excellent constitution of thy legge, it was form'd vn¬≠
der the starre of a Galliard.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
I, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a
dam'd colour'd stocke. Shall we sit about some Reuels?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
What shall we do else: were we not borne vnder
Taurus?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Taurus? That sides and heart.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
No sir, it is leggs and thighes: let me see thee ca¬≠
per. Ha, higher: ha, ha, excellent.

div.head: Scena Quarta.
[Act 1, Scene 4]
div.stage: Enter Valentine, and Viola in mans attire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
If the Duke continue these fauours towards you
Cesario, you are like to be much aduanc'd, he hath known
you but three dayes, and already you are no stranger.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
You either feare his humour, or my negligence,
that you call in question the continuance of his loue. Is
he inconstant sir, in his fauours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No beleeue me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thanke you: heere comes the Count.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who saw Cesario hoa?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: On your attendance my Lord heere.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Stand you a‚Äëwhile aloofe. Cesario,
Thou knowst no lesse, but all: I haue vnclasp'd
To thee the booke euen of my secret soule.
Therefore good youth, addresse thy gate vnto her,
Be not deni'de accesse, stand at her doores,
And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow
Till thou haue audience

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sure my Noble Lord,
If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she neuer will admit me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be clamorous, and leape all ciuill bounds,
Rather then make vnprofited returne,

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Say I do speake with her (my Lord) what then?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O then, vnfold the passion of my loue,
Surprize her with discourse of my deere faith;
It shall become thee well to act my woes:
She will attend it better in thy youth,
Then in a Nuntio's of more graue aspect.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thinke not so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Deere Lad, beleeue it;
For they shall yet belye thy happy yeeres,
That say thou art a man: Dianas lip
Is not more smooth, and rubious: thy small pipe
Is as the maidens organ, shrill, and sound,
And all is semblatiue a womans part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affayre: some foure or fiue attend him,
All if you will: for I my selfe am best
When least in companie: prosper well in this,
And thou shalt liue as freely as thy Lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Ile do my best
To woe your Lady: yet a barrefull strife,
Who ere I woe, my selfe would be his wife.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Nay, either tell me where thou hast bin, or I will
not open my lippes so wide as a brissle may enter, in way
of thy excuse: my Lady will hang thee for thy absence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Let her hang me: hee that is well hang'de in this
world, needs to feare no colours.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Make that good.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He shall see none to feare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
A good lenton answer: I can tell thee where yt
saying was borne, of I feare no colours.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Where good mistris Mary?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
In the warrs, & that may you be bolde to say in
your foolerie.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well, God giue them wisedome that haue it: &
those that are fooles, let them vse their talents.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Yet you will be hang'd for being so long absent,
or to be turn'd away: is not that as good as a hnging to
you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Many a good hanging, preuents a bad marriage:
and for turning away, let summer beare it out.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: You are resolute then?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not so neyther, but I am resolu'd on two points

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
That if one breake, the other will hold: or if both
breake, your gaskins fall.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Apt in good faith, very apt: well go thy way, if
sir Toby would leaue drinking, thou wert as witty a piece
of Eues flesh, as any in Illyria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Peace you rogue, no more o'that: here comes my
Lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Wit, and't be thy will, put me into good fooling:
those wits that thinke they haue thee, doe very oft proue
fooles: and I that am sure I lacke thee, may passe for a
wise man. For what saies Quinapalus, Better a witty foole,
then a foolish wit. God blesse thee Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Take the foole away.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do you not heare fellowes, take away the Ladie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Go too, y'are a dry foole: Ile no more of you: be¬≠
sides you grow dis‚Äëhonest.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Two faults Madona, that drinke & good counsell
wil amend: for giue the dry foole drink, then is the foole
not dry: bid the dishonest man mend himself, if he mend,
he is no longer dishonest; if hee cannot, let the Botcher
mend him: any thing that's mended, is but patch'd: vertu
that transgresses, is but patcht with sinne, and sin that a¬≠
mends, is but patcht with vertue. If that this simple
Sillogisme will serue, so: if it will not, vvhat what remedy?

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.p:
As there is no true Cuckold but calamity, so beauties a
flower; The Lady bad take away the foole, therefore I
say againe, take her away.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, I bad them take away you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Misprision in the highest degree. Lady, Cucullus
non facit monachum: that's as much to say, as I weare not
motley in my braine: good Madona, giue mee leaue to
proue you a foole.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Can you do it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Dexteriously, good Madona.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Make your proofe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I must catechize you for it Madona, Good my
Mouse of vertue answer mee.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Well sir, for want of other idlenesse, Ile bide your
proofe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Good Madona, why mournst thou?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good foole, for my brothers death.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I thinke his soule is in hell, Madona.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I know his soule is in heauen, foole.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The more foole (Madona) to mourne for your
Brothers soule, being in heauen. Take away the Foole,
Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
What thinke you of this foole Maluolio, doth he
not mend?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Yes, and shall do, till the pangs of death shake
him: Infirmity that decaies the wise, doth euer make the
better foole.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
God send you sir, a speedie Infirmity, for the
better increasing your folly: Sir Toby will be sworn that
I am no Fox, but he wil not passe his word for two pence
that you are no Foole.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: How say you to that Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I maruell your Ladyship takes delight in such
a barren rascall: I saw him put down the other day, with
an ordinary foole, that has no more braine then a stone.
Looke you now, he's out of his gard already: vnles you
laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gag'd. I protest
I take these Wisemen, that crow so at these set kinde of
fooles, no better then the fooles Zanies.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
O you are sicke of selfe‚Äëloue Maluolio, and taste
with a distemper'd appetite. To be generous, guiltlesse,
and of free disposition, is to take those things for Bird‚Äë
bolts, that you deeme Cannon bullets: There is no slan¬≠
der in an allow'd foole, though he do nothing but rayle;
nor no rayling, in a knowne discreet man, though hee do
nothing but reproue.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now Mercury indue thee with leasing, for thou
speak'st well of fooles.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Madam, there is at the gate, a young Gentle¬≠
man, much desires to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: From the Count Orsino, is it?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.p:
I know not (Madam) 'tis a faire young man, and
well attended.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Who of my people hold him in delay?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir Toby Madam, your kinsman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Fetch him off I pray you, he speakes nothing but
madman: Fie on him. Go you Maluolio; If it be a suit
from the Count, I am sicke, or not at home. What you
will, to dismisse it.

Now you see sir, how your fooling growes old, & peo¬≠
ple dislike it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Thou hast spoke for vs (Madona) as if thy eldest
sonne should be a foole: who se scull, Ioue cramme with
braines, for heere he comes.
One of thy kin has a most weake Pia‚Äëmater.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
By mine honor halfe drunke. What is he at the
gate Cosin?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: A Gentleman? What Gentleman?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
'Tis a Gentleman heere. A plague o'these pickle
herring: How now Sot.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Good Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Cosin, Cosin, how haue you come so earely by
this Lethargie?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Letcherie, I defie Letchery: there's one at the
gate.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I marry, what is he?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Let him be the diuell and he will, I care not: giue
me faith say I. Well, it's all one.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What's a drunken man like, foole?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Like a drown'd man, a foole, and a madde man:
One draught aboue heate, makes him a foole, the second
maddes him, and a third drownes him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Go thou and seeke the Crowner, and let him sitte
o'my Coz: for he's in the third degree of drinke: hee's
drown'd: go looke after him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
He is but mad yet Madona, and the foole shall
looke to the madman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Madam, yond young fellow sweares hee will
speake with you. I told him you were sicke, he takes on
him to vnderstand so much, and therefore comes to speak
with you. I told him you were asleepe, he seems to haue
a fore knowledge of that too, and therefore comes to
speake with you. What is to be said to him Ladie, hee's
fortified against any deniall.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Tell him, he shall not speake with me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Ha's beene told so: and hee sayes hee'l stand at
your doore like a Sheriffes post, and be the supporter to
a bench, but hee'l speake with you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What kinde o'man is he?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why of mankinde.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What manner of man?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Of verie ill manner: hee'l speake with you, will
you, or no.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Of what personage, and yeeres is he?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Not yet old enough for a man, nor yong enough
for a boy: as a squash is before tis a pescod, or a Codling
when tis almost an Apple: Tis with him in standing wa¬≠
ter, betweene boy and man. He is verie well‚Äëfauour'd,
and he speakes verie shrewishly: One would thinke his
mothers milke were scarse out of him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Let him approach: Call in my Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, my Lady calles.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Giue me my vaile: come throw it ore my face,
Wee'l once more heare Orsinos Embassie.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: The honorable Ladie of the house, which is she?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Speake to me, I shall answer for her: your will.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Most radiant, exquisite, and vnmatchable beau¬≠
tie. I pray you tell me if this bee the Lady of the house,
for I neuer saw her. I would bee loath to cast away my
speech: for besides that it is excellently well pend, I haue
taken great paines to con it. Good Beauties, let mee su¬≠
staine no scorne; I am very comptible, euen to the least
sinister vsage.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Whence came you sir?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I can say little more then I haue studied, & that
question's out of my part. Good gentle one, giue mee
modest assurance, if you be the Ladie of the house, that

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.p: I may proceede in my speech.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Are you a Comedian?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
No my profound heart: and yet (by the verie
phangs of malice, I sweare) I am not that I play. Are you
the Ladie of the house?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: If I do not vsurpe my selfe, I am.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Most certaine, if you are she, you do vsurp your
selfe: for what is yours to bestowe, is, not yours to re¬≠
serue. But this is from my Commission: I will on with
my speech in your praise, and then shew you the heart of
my message.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Come to what is important in't: I forgiue you
the praise.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Alas, I tooke great paines to studie it, and 'tis
Poeticall.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
It is the more like to be feigned, I pray you keep
it in. I heard you were sawcy at my gates, & allowd your
approach rather to wonder at you, then to heare you. If
you be not mad, be gone: if you haue reason, be breefe:
'tis not that time of Moone with me, to make one in so
skipping a dialogue.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Will you hoyst sayle sir, here lies your way.

sp.speaker: Vio.
Ol.
sp.p:
Sure you haue some hiddeous matter to deliuer,
when the curtesie of it is so fearefull. Speake your office.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
It alone concernes your eare: I bring no ouer¬≠
ture of warre, no taxation of homage; I hold the Olyffe
in my hand: my words are as full of peace, as matter.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Yet you began rudely. What are you?
What would you

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
The rudenesse that hath appear'd in mee, haue I
learn'd from my entertainment. What I am, and what I
would, are as secret as maiden‚Äëhead: to your eares, Di¬≠
uinity; to any others, prophanation.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Giue vs the place alone,
We will heare this diuinitie. Now sir, what is your text?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Most sweet Ladie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
A comfortable doctrine, and much may bee saide
of it. Where lies your Text?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: In Orsinoes bosome.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: In his bosome? In what chapter of his bosome?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: To answer by the method in the first of his hart.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
O, I haue read it: it is heresie. Haue you no more
to say?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Good Madam, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Haue you any Commission from your Lord, to
negotiate with my face: you are now out of your Text:
but we will draw the Curtain, and shew you the picture.
Looke you sir, such a one I was this present: Ist not well
done?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Excellently done, if God did all.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
'Tis in graine sir, 'twill endure winde and wea¬≠
ther.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white,
Natures owne sweet, and cunning hand laid on:
Lady, you are the cruell'st shee aliue,
If you will leade these graces to the graue,
And leaue the world no copie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
O sir, I will not be so hard‚Äëhearted: I will giue
out diuers scedules of my beautie. It shalbe Inuentoried
and euery particle and vtensile labell'd to my will: As,
Item two lippes indifferent redde, Item two grey eyes,
with lids to them: Item, one necke, one chin, & so forth.
Were you sent hither to praise me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I see you what you are, you are too proud:
But if you were the diuell, you are faire:
My Lord, and master loues you: O such loue
Could be but recompenc'd, though you were crown'd
The non‚Äëpareil of beautie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: How does he loue me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: With adorations, fertill teares,
With groanes that thunder loue, with sighes of fire.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your Lord does know my mind, I cannot loue him
Yet I suppose him vertuous, know him noble,
Of great estate, of fresh and stainlesse youth;
In voyces well divulg'd, free, learn'd, and valiant,
And in dimension, and the shape of nature,
A gracious person; But yet I cannot loue him:
He might haue tooke his answer long ago.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: If I did loue you in my masters flame,
With such a suffring, such a deadly life:
In your deniall, I would finde no sence,
I would not vnderstand it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why, what would you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Make me a willow Cabine at your gate,
And call vpon my soule within the house,
Write loyall Cantons of contemned loue,
And sing them lowd euen in the dead of night:
Hallow your name to the reuerberate hilles,
And make the babling Gossip of the aire,
Cry out Oliuia: O you should not rest
Betweene the elements of ayre, and earth,
But you should pittie me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You might do much:
What is your Parentage?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Aboue my fortunes, yet my state is well:
I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Get you to your Lord:
I cannot loue him: let him send no more,
Vnlesse (perchance) you come to me againe,
To tell me how he takes it: Fare you well:
I thanke you for your paines: spend this for mee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am no feede poast, Lady; keepe your purse,
My Master, not my selfe, lackes recompence.
Loue make his heart of flint, that you shal loue,
And let your feruour like my masters be,
Plac'd in contempt: Farwell fayre crueltie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What is your Parentage?
Aboue my fortunes, yet my state is well;
I am a Gentleman. Ile be sworne thou art,
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbes, actions, and spirit,
Do giue thee fiue‚Äëfold blazon: not too fast: soft, soft,
Vnlesse the Master were the man. How now?
Euen so quickly may one catch the plague?
Me thinkes I feele this youths perfections
With an inuisible, and subtle stealth
To creepe in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.
What hoa, Maluolio.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Heere Madam, at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Run after that same peeuish Messenger
The Countes man: he left this Ring behinde him
Would I, or not: tell him, Ile none of it.
Desire him not to flatter with his Lord,
Nor hold him vp with hopes, I am not for him:
If that the youth will come this way to morrow,
Ile giue him reasons for't: hie thee Maluolio.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I do I know not what, and feare to finde
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my minde:

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Fate, shew thy force, our selues we do not owe,
What is decreed, must be: and be this so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Will you stay no longer: nor will you not that
I go with you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
By your patience, no: my starres shine darkely
ouer me; the malignancie of my fate, might perhaps di¬≠
temper yours; therefore I shall craue of you your leaue,
that I may beare my euils alone. It were a bad recom¬≠
pence for your loue, to lay any of them on you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Let me yet know of you, whither you are bound.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
No sooth sir: my determinate voyage is meere
extrauagancie. But I perceiue in you so excellent a touch
of modestie, that you will not extort from me, what I am
willing to keepe in: therefore it charges me in manners,
the rather to expresse my selfe: you must know of mee
then Antonio, my name is Sebastian (which I call'd Rodo¬≠
rigo) my father was that Sebastian of Messaline, whom I
know you haue heard of. He left behinde him, my selfe,
and a sister, both borne in an houre: if the Heauens had
beene pleas'd, would we had so ended. But you sir, al¬≠
tered that, for some houre before you tooke me from the
breach of the sea, was my sister drown'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alas the day.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
A Lady sir, though itwas said shee much resem¬≠
bled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but thogh
I could not with such estimable wonder ouer‚Äëfarre be¬≠
leeue that, yet thus farre I will boldly publish her, shee
bore a minde that enuy could not but call faire: Shee is
drown'd already sir with salt water, though I seeme to
drowne her remembrance againe with more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, your bad entertainment.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: O good Antonio, forgiue me your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
If you will not murther me for my loue, let me
be your seruant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
If you will not vndo what you haue done, that is
kill him, whom you haue recouer'd, desire it not. Fare
ye well at once, my bosome is full of kindnesse, and I
am yet so neere the manners of my mother, that vpon the
least occasion more, mine eyes will tell tales of me: I am
bound to the Count Orsino's Court, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The gentlenesse of all the gods go with thee:
I haue many enemies in Orsino's Court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there:
But come what may, I do adore thee so,
That danger shall seeme sport, and I will go.

div.head: Sc√¶na Secunda.
[Act 2, Scene 2]
div.stage: Enter Viola and Maluolio, at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Were not you eu'n now, with the Countesse O¬≠
liuia?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Euen now sir, on a moderate pace, I haue since a¬≠
riu'd but hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
She returnes this Ring to you (sir) you might
haue saued mee my paines, to haue taken it away your
selfe. She adds moreouer, that you should put your Lord

into a desperate assurance, she will none of him. And one
thing more, that you be neuer so hardie to come againe
in his affaires, vnlesse it bee to report your Lords taking
of this: receiue it so.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: She tooke the Ring of me, Ile none of it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Come sir, you peeuishly threw it to her: and
her will is, it should be so return'd: If it bee worth stoo¬≠
ping for, there it lies, in your eye: if not, bee it his that
findes it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I left no Ring with her: what meanes this Lady?
Fortune forbid my out‚Äëside haue not charm'd her:
She made good view of me, indeed so much,
That me thought her eyes had lost her tongue,
For she did speake in starts distractedly.
She loues me sure, the cunning of her passion
Inuites me in this churlish messenger:
None of my Lords Ring? Why he sent her none;
I am the man, if it be so, as tis,
Poore Lady, she were better loue a dreame:
Disguise, I see thou art a wickednesse,
Wherein the pregnant enemie does much.
How easie is it, for the proper false
In womens waxen hearts to set their formes:
Alas, O frailtie is the cause, not wee,
For such as we are made, if such we bee:
How will this fadge? My master loues her deerely,
And I (poore monster) fond asmuch on him:
And she (mistaken) seemes to dote on me:
What will become of this? As I am man,
My state is desperate for my maisters loue:
As I am woman (now alas the day)
What thriftlesse sighes shall poore Oliuia breath?
O time, thou must vntangle this, not I,
It is too hard a knot for me t'vnty.

div.head: Sc≈ìna Tertia.
[Act 2, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, and Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Approach Sir Andrew: not to bee a bedde after
midnight, is to be vp betimes, and Deliculo surgere, thou
know'st.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Nay by my troth I know not: but I know, to
be vp late, is to be vp late.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
A false conclusion: I hate it as an vnfill'd Canne.
To be vp after midnight, and to go to bed then is early:
so that to go to bed after midnight, is to goe to bed be¬≠
times. Does not our liues consist of the foure Ele¬≠
ments?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Faith so they say, but I thinke it rather consists
of eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Th'art a scholler; let vs therefore eate and drinke
Marian I say, a stoope of wine.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Heere comes the foole yfaith.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
How now my harts: Did you neuer see the Pic¬≠
ture of we three?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Welcome asse, now let's haue a catch.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
By my troth the foole has an excellent breast. I
had rather then forty shillings I had such a legge, and so
sweet a breath to sing, as the foole has. Insooth thou wast
in very gracious fooling last night, when thou spok'st of
Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians pasing the Equinoctial of
Queubus: 'twas very good yfaith: I sent thee sixe pence

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.p: for thy Lemon, hadst it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I did impeticos thy gratillity: for Maluolios nose
is no Whip‚Äëstocke. My Lady has a white hand, and the
Mermidons are no bottle‚Äëale houses.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Excellent: Why this is the best fooling, when
all is done. Now a song.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come on, there is sixe pence for you. Let's haue
a song.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There's a testrill of me too: if one knight giue a

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Would you haue a loue‚Äësong, or a song of good
life?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A loue song, a loue song.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I, I. I care not for good life.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: O Mistris mine where are you roming?
O stay and heare, your true loues coming,
That can sing both high and low.
Trip no further prettie sweeting.
Iourneys end in louers meeting,
Euery wise mans sonne doth know.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Excellent good, ifaith.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What is loue, tis not heereafter,
Present mirth, hath present laughter:
What's to come, is still vnsure.
In delay there lies no plentie,
Then come kisse me sweet and twentie:
Youths a stuffe will not endure.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A mellifluous voyce, as I am true knight.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A contagious breath.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Very sweet, and contagious ifaith.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
To heare by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.
But shall we make the Welkin dance indeed? Shall wee
rowze the night‚ÄëOwle in a Catch, that will drawe three
soules out of one Weauer? Shall we do that?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
And you loue me, let's doo't: I am dogge at a
Catch.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Byrlady sir, and some dogs will catch well.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Most crtaine: Let our Catch be, Thou Knaue.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Hold thy peace, thou Knaue knight. I shall be con¬≠
strained in't, to call thee knaue, Knight.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
'Tis not the first time I haue constrained one to
call me knaue. Begin foole: it begins, Hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I shall neuer begin if I hold my peace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Good ifaith: Come begin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
What a catterwalling doe you keepe heere? If
my Ladie haue not call'd vp her Steward Maluolio, and
bid him turne you out of doores, neuer trust me.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
My Lady's a Catayan, we are politicians, Maluolios
a Peg‚Äëa‚Äëramsie, and Three merry men be wee. Am not I
consanguinious? Am I not of her blood: tilly vally. La¬≠
die, There dwelt a man in Babylon, Lady, Lady.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Beshrew me, the knights in admirable fooling.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
I, he do's well enough if he be dispos'd, and so
do I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it more
naturall.

p.hi: O the twelfe day of December.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For the loue o' God peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
My masters are you mad? Or what are you?
Haue you no wit, manners, nor honestie, but to gabble
like Tinkers at this time of night? Do yee make an Ale¬≠
house of my Ladies house, that ye squeak out your Cozi¬≠
ers Catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice?
Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: We did keepe time sir in our Catches. Snecke vp.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My Lady
bad me tell you, that though she harbors you as her kins¬≠
man, she's nothing ally'd to your disorders. If you can
separate your selfe and your misdemeanors, you are wel¬≠
come to the house: if not, and it would please you to take
leaue of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Farewell deere heart, since I must needs be gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay good Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: His eyes do shew his dayes are almost done.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is't euen so?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: But I will neuer dye.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sir Toby there you lye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This is much credit to you.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall I bid him go.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What and if you do?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall I bid him go, and spare not?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O no, no, no, no, you dare not.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Out o' tune sir, ye lye: Art any more then a Stew¬≠
ard? Dost thou thinke because thou art vertuous, there
shall be no more Cakes and Ale?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Yes by
S. Saint
Anne, and Ginger shall bee hotte y'th
mouth too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Th'art i'th right. Goe sir, rub your Chaine with
crums. A stope of Wine Maria.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Mistris Mary, if you priz'd my Ladies fauour
at any thing more then contempt, you would not giue
meanes for this vnciuill rule; she shall know of it by this
hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Go shake your eares.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
'Twere as good a deede as to drink when a mans
a hungrie, to challenge him the field, and then to breake
promise with him, and make a foole of him.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Doo't knight, Ile write thee a Challenge: or Ile
deliuer thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sweet Sir Toby be patient for to night: Since
the youth of the Counts was to day with my Lady, she is
much out of quiet. For Monsieur Maluolio, let me alone
with him: If I do not gull him into an ayword, and make
him a common recreation, do not thinke I haue witte e¬≠
nough to lye straight in my bed: I know I can do it.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Possesse vs, possesse vs, tell vs something of him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marrie sir, sometimes he is a kinde of Puritane.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O, if I thought that, Ide beate him like a dogge.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
What for being a Puritan, thy exquisite reason,
deere knight.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
I haue no exquisite reason for't, but I haue reason
good enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The diu'll a Puritane that hee is, or any thing
constantly but a time‚Äëpleaser, an affection'd Asse, that
cons State without booke, and vtters it by great swarths.
The best perswaded of himselfe: so cram'd (as he thinkes)
with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith, that all
that looke on him, loue him: and on that vice in him, will
my reuenge finde notable cause to worke.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: What wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I will drop in his way some obscure Epistles of
loue, wherein by the colour of his beard, the shape of his
legge, the manner of his gate, the expressure of his eye,
forehead, and complection, he shall finde himselfe most
feelingly personated. I can write very like my Ladie
your Neece, on a forgotten matter wee can hardly make
distinction of our hands.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Excellent, I smell a deuice.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I hau't in my nose too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: He shall thinke by the Letters that thou wilt drop

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.p:
that they come from my Neece, and that shee's in loue
with him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My purpose is indeed a horse of that colour.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And your horse now would make him an Asse.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Asse, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O twill be admirable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sport royall I warrant you: I know my Phy¬≠
sicke will worke with him, I will plant you two, and let
the Foole make a third, where he shall finde the Letter:
obserue his construction of it: For this night to bed, and
dreame on the euent: Farewell.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Good night Penthisilea.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Before me she's a good wench.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
She's a beagle true bred, and one that adores me:
what o'that?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I was ador'd once too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Let's to bed knight: Thou hadst neede send for
more money.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
If I cannot recouer your Neece, I am a foule way
out.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Send for money knight, if thou hast her not i'th
end, call me Cut.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If I do not, neuer trust me, take it how you will.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come, come, Ile go burne some Sacke, tis too late
to go to bed now: Come knight, come knight.

div.head: Scena Quarta.
[Act 2, Scene 4]
div.stage: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and others.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Giue me some Musick; Now good morow frends.
Now good Cesario, but that peece of song,
That old and Anticke song we heard last night;
Me thought it did releeue my passion much,
More then light ayres, and recollected termes
Of these most briske and giddy‚Äëpaced times.
Come, but one verse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
He is not heere (so please your Lordshippe) that
should sing it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Feste the Iester my Lord, a foole that the Ladie
Oliuiaes Father tooke much delight in. He is about the
house.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Seeke him out, and play the tune the while.
sp.l: Come hither Boy, if euer thou shalt loue
In the sweet pangs of it, remember me:
For such as I am, all true Louers are,
Vnstaid and skittish in all motions else,
Saue in the constant image of the creature
That is belou'd. How dost thou like this tune?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: It giues a verie eccho to the seate
Where loue is thron'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou dost speake masterly,
My life vpon't, yong though thou art, thine eye
Hath staid vpon some fauour that it loues:
Hath it not boy?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: A little, by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What kinde of woman ist?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Of your complection.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She is not worth thee then. What yeares ifaith?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: About your yeeres my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Too old by heauen: Let still the woman take
An elder then her selfe, so weares she to him;
So swayes she leuell in her husbands heart:
For boy, howeuer we do praise our selues,
Our fancies are more giddie and vnfirme,
More longing, wauering, sooner lost and worne,
Then womens are.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thinke it well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then let thy Loue be yonger then thy selfe,
Or thy affection cannot hold the bent:
For women are as Roses, whose faire flowre
Being once displaid, doth fall that verie howre.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And so they are: alas, that they are so:
To die, euen when they to perfection grow.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O fellow come, the song we had last night:
Marke it Cesario, it is old and plaine;
The Spinsters and the Knitters in the Sun,
And the free maides that weaue their thred with bones,
Do vse to chaunt it: it is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of loue,
Like the old age.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are you ready Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I prethee sing.

div.l: And in sad cypresse let me be laide.
I am slaine by a faire cruell maide:
My shrowd of white, stuck all with Ew, O prepare it.
My part of death no one so true did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweete
On my blacke coffin, let there be strewne:
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poore corpes, where my bones shall be throwne:
A thousand thousand sighes to saue, lay me √¥ where
Sad true louer neuer find my graue, to weepe there.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There's for thy paines.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No paines sir, I take pleasure in singing sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ile pay thy pleasure then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truely sir, and pleasure will be paide one time, or
another.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Giue me now leaue, to leaue thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now the melancholly God protect thee, and the
Tailor make thy doublet of changeable Taffata, for thy
minde is a very Opall. I would haue men of such constan¬≠
cie put to Sea, that their businesse might be euery thing,
and their intent euerie where, for that's it, that alwayes
makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let all the rest giue place: Once more Cesario,
Get thee to yond same soueraigne crueltie:
Tell her my loue, more noble then the world
Prizes not quantitie of dirtie lands,
The parts that fortune hath bestow'd vpon her:
Tell her I hold as giddily as Fortune:
But 'tis that miracle, and Queene of Iems
That nature prankes her in, attracts my soule.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But if she cannot loue you sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: It cannot be so answer'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sooth but you must.
Say that some Lady, as perhappes there is,
Hath for your loue as great a pang of heart
As you haue for Oliuia: you cannot loue her:
You tel her so: Must she not then be answer'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There is no womans sides

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Can bide the beating of so strong a pass sion,
As loue doth giue my heart: no womans heart
So bigge, to hold so much, they lacke retention.
Alas, their loue may be call'd appetite,
No motion of the Liuer, but the Pallat,
That suffer surfet, cloyment, and reuolt,An ink mark follows the end of this line.
But mine is all as hungry as the Sea,
And can digest as much, make no compare
Betweene that loue a woman can beare me,
And that I owe Oliuia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I but I know.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What dost thou knowe?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Too well what loue women to men may owe:
In faith they are as true of heart, as we.
My Father had a daughter lou'd a man
As it might be perhaps, were I a woman
I should your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And what's her history?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: A blanke my Lord: she neuer told her loue,
But let concealment like a worme i'th budde
Feede on her damaske cheeke: she pin'd in thought,
And with a greene and yellow melancholly,
She sate like Patience on a Monument,
Smiling at greefe. Was not this loue indeede?
We men may say more, sweare more, but indeed
Our shewes are more then will: for still we proue
Much in our vowes, but little in our loue.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But di'de thy sister of her loue my Boy?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am all the daughters of my Fathers house,
And all the brothers too: and yet I know not.
Sir, shall I to this Lady?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I that's the Theame,
To her in haste: giue her this Iewell: say,
My loue can giue no place, bide no denay.

div.head: Scena Quinta.
[Act 2, Scene 5]
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Come thy wayes Signior Fabian.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nay Ile come: if I loose a scruple of this sport,
let me be boyl'd to death with Melancholly.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Wouldst thou not be glad to haue the niggard¬≠
ly Rascally sheepe‚Äëbiter, come by some notable shame?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I would exult man: you know he brought me out
o'fauour with my Lady, about a Beare‚Äëbaiting heere.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
To anger him wee'l haue the Beare againe, and
we will foole him blacke and blew, shall we not sir An¬≠
drew?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And we do not, it is pittie of our liues.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Heere comes the little villaine: How now my
Mettle of India?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get ye all three into the box tree: Maluolio's
comming downe this walke, he has beene yonder i'the
Sunne practising behauiour to his own shadow this halfe
houre: obserue him for the loue of Mockerie: for I know
this Letter wil make a contemplatiue Ideot of him. Close
in the name of ieasting, lye thou there: for heere comes
the Trowt, that must be caught with tickling.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Tis but Fortune, all is fortune. Maria once
told me she did affect me, and I haue heard her self come
thus neere, that should shee fancie, it should bee one of
my complection. Besides she vses me with a more ex¬≠
alted respect, then any one else that followes her. What
should I thinke on't?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Heere's an ouer‚Äëweening rogue.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Oh peace: Contemplation makes a rare Turkey
Cocke of him, how he iets vnder his aduanc'd plumes.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Slight I could so beate the Rogue.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Peace I say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To be Count Maluolio.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Ah Rogue.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Pistoll him, pistoll him.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
There is example for't: The Lady of the Stra¬≠
chy, married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Fie on him Iezabel.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
O peace, now he's deepely in: looke how imagi¬≠
nation blowes him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Hauing beene three moneths married to her,
sitting in my state.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: O for a stone‚Äëbow to hit him in the eye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Calling my Officers about me, in my branch'd
Veluet gowne: hauing come from a day bedde, where I
haue left Oliuia sleeping.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Fire and Brimstone.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: O peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
And then to haue the humor of state: and after
a demure trauaile of regard: telling them I knowe my
place, as I would they should doe theirs: to aske for my
kinsman Toby.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Boltes and shackles.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh peace, peace, peace, now, now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Seauen of my people with an obedient start,
make out for him: I frowne the while, and perchance
winde vp my watch, or play with my some rich Iewell:
Toby approaches; curtsies there to me.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Shall this fellow liue?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Though our silence be drawne from vs with cars,
yet peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l:
I extend my hand to him thus: quenching my
familiar smile with an austere regard of controll.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
And do's not Toby take you a blow o'the lippes,
then?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Saying, Cosine Toby, my Fortunes hauing cast
me on your Neece, giue me this prerogatiue of speech.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You must amend your drunkennesse.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Out scab.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nay patience, or we breake the sinewes of our
plot?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Besides you waste the treasure of your time,
with a foolish knight.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: That's mee I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: One sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I knew 'twas I, for many do call mee foole.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What employment haue we heere?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Now is the Woodcocke neere the gin.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Oh peace, and the spirit of humors intimate rea¬≠
ding aloud to him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
By my life this is my Ladies hand: these bee her
very C s, her V's, and her T's, and thus makes shee het her
great P's. It is in contempt of question her hand.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Her C's, her V's, and her T's: why that?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
To the vnknowne belou'd, this, and my good Wishes:
Her very Phrases: By your leaue wax. Soft, and the im¬≠
pressure her Lucrece, with which she vses to seale: tis my
Lady: To whom should this be?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: This winnes him, Liuer and all.

fw.hi: Mal.
Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Ioue knowes I loue, but who, Lips do not mooue, no
man must know. No man must know. What followes?
The numbers alter d: No man must know,
If this should be thee Maluolio?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Marrie hang thee brocke.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l:
I may command where I adore, but silence like a Lu¬≠
cresse knife:

With bloodlesse stroke my heart doth gore, M.O.A.I. doth
sway my life.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A fustian riddle.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Excellent Wench, say I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M.O.A.I. doth sway my life. Nay but first
let me see, let me see, let me see.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What dish a poyson has she drest him?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And with what wing the stallion checkes at it?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I may command, where I adore: Why shee may
command me: I serue her, she is my Ladie. Why this is
euident to any formall capacitie. There is no obstruction
in this, and the end: What should that Alphabeticall po¬≠
sition portend, if I could make that resemble something
in me? Softly, M.O.A.I.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: O I, make vp that, he is now at a cold sent.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Sowter will cry vpon't for all this, though it bee
as ranke as a Fox.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: M. Maluolio, M: why that begins my name.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Did not I say he would worke it out, the Curre
is excellent at faults.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M. But then there is no consonancy in the sequell
that suffers vnder probation: A. should follow, but O.
does.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: And O shall end, I hope.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I, or Ile cudgell him, and make him cry O.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And then I. comes behind.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I, and you had any eye behinde you, you might
see more detraction at your heeles, then Fortunes before
you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M,O,A,I. This simulation is not as the former:
and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to mee, for e¬≠
uery one of these Letters are in my name. Soft, here fol¬≠
lowes prose: If this fall into thy hand, reuolue. In my stars
I am aboue thee, but be not affraid of greatnesse: Some
are become great, some atcheeues greatnesse, and some
haue greatnesse thrust vppon em. Thy fates open theyr
hands, let thy blood and spirit embrace them, and to in¬≠
ure thy selfe to what thou art like to be:cast thy humble
slough, and appeare fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman,
surly with seruants: Let thy tongue tang arguments of
state; put thy selfe into the tricke of singularitie. Shee
thus aduises thee, that sighes for thee. Remember who
commended thy yellow stockings, and wish'd to see thee
euer crosse garter'd: I say remember, goe too, thou art
made if thou desir'st to be so: If not, let me see thee a ste¬≠
ward still, the fellow of seruants, and not woorthie to
touch Fortunes fingers Farewell, Shee that would alter
seruices with thee, the fortunate vnhappy daylight and
champian discouers not more: This is open, I will bee
proud, I will reade politicke Authours, I will baffle Sir
Toby, I will wash off grosse acquaintance, I will be point
deuise, the very man. I do not now foole my selfe, to let
imagination iade mee; for euery reason excites to this,
that my Lady loues m√®. She did commend my yellow
stockings of late, shee did praise my legge being crosse‚Äë
garter'd, and in this she manifests her selfe to my loue, &
with a kinde of iniunction driues mee to these habites of
her liking. I thanke my starres, I am happy: I will bee
strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and crosse Garter'd,
euen with the swiftnesse of putting on. Ioue, and my
starres be praised. Heere is yet a postscript. Thou canst
not choose but know who I am. If thou entertainst my loue, let
it appeare in thy smiling, thy smiles become thee well. There¬≠
fore in my presence still smile, deere my sweete, I prethee. Ioue
I thanke thee, I will smile, I wil do euery thing that thou
wilt haue me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I will not giue my part of this sport for a pensi¬≠
on of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I could marry this wench for this deuice.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: So could I too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
And aske no other dowry with her, but such ano¬≠
ther iest.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Heere comes my noble gull catcher.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Wilt thou set thy foote o'my necke.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Or o'mine either?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Shall I play my freedome at tray‚Äëtrip, and becom
thy bondslaue?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ifaith, or I either?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
Why, thou hast put him in such a dreame, that
when the image of it leaues him, he must run mad.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Nay but say true, do's it worke vpon him?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Like Aqua vite with a Midwife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If you will then see the fruites of the sport, mark
his first approach before my Lady: hee will come to her
in yellow stockings, and 'tis a colour she abhorres, and
crosse garter'd, a fashion shee detests: and hee will smile
vpon her, which will now be so vnsuteable to her dispo¬≠
sition, being addicted to a melancholly, as shee is, that it
cannot but turn him into a notable contempt: if you wil
see it follow me.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent diuell
of wit.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Ile make one too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Saue thee Friend and thy Musick: dost thou liue
by thy Tabor?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No sir, I liue by the Church.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Art thou a Churchman?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No such matter sir, I do liue by the Church: For,
I do liue at my house, and my house dooth stand by the
Church.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
So thou maist say the Kings lyes by a begger, if a
begger dwell neer him: or the Church stands by thy Ta¬≠
bor, if thy Tabor stand by the Church.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You haue said sir: To see this age: A sentence is
but a cheu'rill gloue to a good witte, how quickely the
wrong side may be turn'd outward.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Nay that's certaine: they that dally nicely with
words, may quickely make them wanton.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I would therefore my sister had had no name Sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why sir, her names a word, and to dallie with
that word, might make my sister wanton: But indeede,
words are very Rascals, since bonds disgrac'd them.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thy reason man?

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Troth sir, I can yeeld you none without wordes,
and wordes are growne so false, I am loath to proue rea¬≠
son with them.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I warrant thou art a merry fellow, and car'st for
nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Not so sir, I do care for something: but in my con¬≠
science sir, I do not care for you: if that be to care for no¬≠
thing sir, I would it would make you inuisible.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Art not thou the Lady Oliuia's foole?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No indeed sir, the Lady Oliuia has no folly, shee
will keepe no foole sir, till she be married, and fooles are
as like husbands, as Pilchers are to Herrings, the Hus¬≠
bands the bigger, I am indeede not her foole, but hir cor¬≠
rupter of words.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Foolery sir, does walke about the Orbe like the
sun, it shines euery where. I would be sorry sir, but the
foole should be as oft with your Master, as with my Mi¬≠
stris: I thinke I saw your wisedome there.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Nay, and thou passe vpon me, Ile no more with
thee Hold there's expences for thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now Ioue in his next commodity of hayre, send
thee a beard.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
By my troth Ile tell thee, I am almost sicke for
one, though I would not haue it grow on my chinne. Is
my Lady within?

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.p: Would not a paire of these haue bred sir?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes being kept together, and put to vse.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia sir, to bring
a Cresssida to this Troylus.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I vnderstand you sir, tis well begg'd.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The matter I hope is not great sir; begging, but a
begger: Cresssida was a begger. My Lady is within sir. I
will conster to them whence you come, who you are, and
what you would are out of my welkin, I might say Ele¬≠
ment, but the word is ouer‚Äëworne.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: This fellow is wise enough to play the foole,
And to do that well, craues a kind of wit:
He must obserue their mood on whom he iests,
The quality of persons, and the time:
And like the Haggard, checke at euery Feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practice,
As full of labour as a Wise‚Äëmans Art:
For folly that he wisely shewes, is fit;
But wisemens folly falne, quite taint their wit.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Saue you Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you sir.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Dieu vou guard Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Et vouz ousie vostre seruiture.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I hope sir, you are, and I am yours.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Will you incounter the house, my Neece is desi¬≠¬≠
rous you should enter, if your trade be to her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I am bound to your Neece sir, I meane she is the
list of my voyage.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Taste your legges sir, put them to motion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
My legges do better vnderstand me sir, then I vn¬≠
derstand what you meane by bidding me taste my legs.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I meane to go sir, to enter.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I will answer you with gate and entrance, but we
are preuented.

Most excellent accomplish'd Lady, the heauens raine O¬≠
dours on you.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: That youth's a rare Courtier, raine odours, wel.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
My matter hath no voice Lady, but to your owne
most pregnant and vouchsafed eare.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Odours, pregnant, and vouchsafed: Ile get 'em
all three already.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Let the Garden doore be shut, and leaue mee to
my hearing. Giue me your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My dutie Madam, and most humble seruiceAn ink mark follows the end of this line.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Cesario is your seruants name, faire Princesse.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: My seruant sir? 'Twas neuer merry world,
Since lowly feigning was call'd complement:
y'are seruant to the Count Orsino youth.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:
your seruants seruant, is your seruant Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: For him, I thinke not on him: for his thoughts,
Would they were blankes, rather then fill'd with me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalfe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O by your leaue I pray you.
I bad you neuer speake againe of him;
But would you vndertake another suite
I had rather heare you, to solicit that,
Then Musicke from the spheares.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Deere Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Giue me leaue, beseech you: I did send,
After the last enchantment you did heare,
A Ring in chace of you. So did I abuse
My selfe, my seruant, and I feare me you:
Vnder your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you in a shamefull cunning
Which you knew none of yours. What might you think?
Haue you not set mine Honor at the stake,
And baited it with all th'vnmuzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiuing
Enough is shewne, a Cipresse, not a bosome,
Hides my heart: so let me heare you speake.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I pittie you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That's a degree to loue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No not a grize: for tis a vulgar proofe
That verie oft we pitty enemies.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why then me thinkes 'tis time to smile agen:
O world, how apt the poore are to be proud?
If one should be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the Lion, then the Wolfe?
The clocke vpbraides me with the waste of time:
Be not affraid good youth, I will not haue you,
And yet when wit and youth is come to haruest,
your wife is like to reape a proper man:
There lies your way, due West.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then Westward hoe:
Grace and good disposition attend your Ladyship:
You'l nothing Madam to my Lord, by me:

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Stay: I prethee tell me what thou thinkst of me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: That you do thinke you are not what you are.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If I thinke so, I thinke the same of you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then thinke you right: I am not what I am.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I would you were, as I would haue you be.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Would it be better Madam, then I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your foole.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O what a deale of scorne, lookes beautifull?
In the contempt and anger of his lip,
A murdrous guilt shewes not it selfe more soone,
Then loue that would seeme hid: Loues night, is noone.
Cesario, by the Roses of the Spring,
By maid‚Äëhood, honor, truth, and euery thing,
I loue thee so, that maugre all thy pride,

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Nor wit, nor reason, can my passion hide:
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause:
But rather reason thus, with reason fetter;
Loue sought, is good: but giuen vnsought, is better.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: By innocence I sweare, and by my youth,
I haue one heart, one bosome, and one truth,
And that no woman has, nor neuer none
Shall mistris be of it, saue I alone.
And so adieu good Madam, neuer more,
Will I my Masters teares to you deplore.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Yet come againe: for thou perhaps mayst moue
That heart which now abhorres, to like his loue.

div.head: Sc≈ìna Secunda.
[Act 3, Scene 2]
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: No faith, Ile not stay a iot longer:

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Thy reason deere venom, giue thy reason.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
You must needes yeelde your reason, Sir An¬≠
drew?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Marry I saw your Neece do more fauours to the
Counts Seruing‚Äêman, then euer she bestow'd vpon mee:
I saw't i'th Orchard.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Did she see the while, old boy, tell me that.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: As plaine as I see you now.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This was a great argument of loue in her toward
you.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: S'light; will you make an Asse o'me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I will proue it legitimate sir, vpon the Oathes of
iudgement, and reason.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
And they haue beene grand Iurie men, since before
Noah was a Saylor.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Shee did shew fauour to the youth in your sight,
onely to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valour,
to put fire in your Heart, and brimstone in your Liuer:
you should then haue accosted her, and with some excel¬≠
lent iests, fire‚Äënew from the mint, you should haue bangd
the youth into dumbenesse: this was look'd for at your
hand, and this was baulkt: the double gilt of this oppor¬≠
tunitie you let time wash off, and you are now sayld into
the North of my Ladies opinion, where you will hang
like an ysickle on a Dutchmans beard, vnlesse you do re¬≠
deeme it, by some laudable attempt, either of valour or
policie.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
And't be any way, it must be with Valour, for
policie I hate: I had as liefe be a Brownist, as a Politi¬≠
cian.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Why then build me thy fortunes vpon the basis of
valour. Challenge me the Counts youth to fight with him
hurt him in eleuen places, my Neece shall take note of it,
and assure thy selfe, there is no loue‚ÄëBroker in the world,
can more preuaile in mans commendation with woman,
then report of valour.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: There is no way but this sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Will either of you beare me a challenge to him?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Go, write it in a martial hand, be curst and briefe:
it is no matter how wittie, so it bee eloquent, and full of
inuention: taunt him with the license of Inke: if thou
thou'st him some thrice, it shall not be amisse, and as ma¬≠
ny Lyes, as will lye in thy sheete of paper, although the
sheete were bigge enough for the bedde of Ware in Eng¬≠

land, set 'em downe, go about it. Let there bee gaulle e¬≠
nough in thy inke, though thou write with a Goose‚Äëpen,
no matter: about it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Where shall I finde you?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Wee'l call thee at the Cubiculo: Go.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: This is a deere Manakin to you Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I haue beene deere to him lad, some two thousand
strong, or so.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
We shall haue a rare Letter from him; but you'le
not deliuer't.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Neuer trust me then: and by all meanes stirre on
the youth to an answer. I thinke Oxen and waine‚Äëropes
cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were open'd
and you finde so much blood in his Liuer, as will clog the
foote of a flea, Ile eate the rest of th' anatomy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
And his opposit the youth beares in his visage no
great presage of cruelty.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Looke where the youngest Wren of mine comes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If you desire the spleene, and will laughe your
selues into stitches, follow me; yond gull Maluolio is tur¬≠
ned Heathen, a verie Renegatho; for there is no christian
that meanes to be saued by beleeuing rightly, can euer
beleeue such imposssible passages of grossenesse. Hee's in
yellow stockings.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And crosse garter'd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Most villanously: like a Pedant that keepes a
Schoole i'th Church: I haue dogg'd him like his murthe¬≠
rer. He does obey euery point of the Letter that I dropt,
to betray him: He does smile his face into more lynes,
then is in the new Mappe, with the augmentation of the
Indies: you haue not seene such a thing as tis: I can hard¬≠
ly forbeare hurling things at him, I know my Ladie will
strike him: if shee doe, hee'l smile, and take't for a great
fauour.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Come bring vs, bring vs where he is.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would not by my will haue troubled you,
But since you make your pleasure of your paines,
I will no further chide you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I could not stay behinde you: my desire
(More sharpe then filed steele) did spurre me forth,
And not all loue to see you (though so much
As might haue drawne one to a longer voyage)
But iealousie, what might befall your rrauell trauell ,
Being skillesse in these parts: which to a stranger,
Vnguided, and vnfriended, often proue
Rough, and vnhospitable. My willing loue,An ink mark follows the end of this line.
The rather by these arguments of feare
Set forth in your pursuite.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My kinde Anthonio,
I can no other answer make, but thankes,
And thankes: and euer oft good turnes,
Are shuffel'd off with such vncurrant pay:
But were my worth, as is my conscience firme,

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: You should finde better dealing: what's to do?
Shall we go see the reliques of this Towne?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To morrow sir, best first go see your Lodging?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I am not weary, and 'tis long to night
I pray you let vs satisfie our eyes
With the memorials, and the things of fame
That do renowne this City.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would youl'd pardon me:
I do not without danger walke these streetes.
Once in a sea‚Äëfight 'gainst the Count his gallies,
I did some seruice, of such note indeede,
That were I tane heere, it would scarse be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Belike you slew great number of his people.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Th offence is not of such a bloody nature,
Albeit the quality of the time, and quarrell
Might well haue giuen vs bloody argument:
It might haue since bene answer'd in repaying
What we tooke from them, which for Traffiques sake
Most of our City did. Onely my selfe stood out,
or which if I be lapsed in this place
I shall pay deere.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do not then walke too open.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It doth not fit me: hold sir, here's my purse,
In the South Suburbes at the Elephant
Is best to lodge: I will bespeake our dyet,
