Whiles you beguile the time, and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the Towne, there shall you haue me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why I your purse?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Haply your eye shall light vpon some toy
You haue desire to purchase: and your store
I thinke is not for idle Markets, sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ile be your purse‚Äëbearer, and leaue you
For an houre.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To th'Elephant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I do remember.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I haue sent after him, he sayes hee'l come:
How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft, then begg'd, or borrow'd.
I speake too loud: Where's Maluolio, he is sad, and ciuill,
And suites well for a seruant with my fortunes,
Where is Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's comming Madame:
But in very strange manner. He is sure possest Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why what's the matter, does he raue?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No Madam, he does nothing but smile: your La¬≠
dyship were best to haue some guard about you, if hee
come, for sure the man is tainted in's wits.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Go call him hither.
I am as madde as hee,
If sad and metry merry madnesse equall bee.
How now Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Smil'st thou? I sent for thee vpon a sad occasion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sad Lady, I could be sad:
This does make some obstruction in the blood:
This crosse‚Äëgartering, but what of that?
If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true
Sonnet is: Please one, and please all.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.note: This speech is conventionally attributed to Olivia.
sp.l: Why how doest thou man?
What is the matter with thee?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Not blacke in my minde, though yellow in my
legges: It did come to his hands, and Commaunds shall
be executed. I thinke we doe know the sweet Romane
hand.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Wilt thou go to bed Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To bed? I sweet heart, and Ile come to thee.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
God comfort thee: Why dost thou smile so, and
kisse thy hand so oft?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Maluo.
sp.l: At your request:
Yes Nightingales answere Dawes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why appeare you with this ridiculous bold¬≠
nesse before my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Be not afraid of greatnesse: 'twas well writ.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What meanst thou by that Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Some are borne great.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Some atcheeue greatnesse.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And some haue greatnesse thrust vpon them.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Heauen restore thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Remember who commended thy yellow stock¬≠
ings.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Thy yellow stockings?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And wish'd to see thee crosse garter'd.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Crosse garter'd?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Go too, thou art made,if thou desir'st to be so.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Am I made?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If not, let me see thee a seruant still.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why this is verie Midsommer madnesse.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Madame, the young Gentleman of the Count
Orsino's is return'd, I could hardly entreate him backe: he
attends your Ladyships pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Ile come to him.

Good Maria, let this fellow be look d too. Where's my
Cosine Toby, let some of my people haue a speciall care
of him, I would not haue him miscarrie for the halfe of
my Dowry.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Oh ho, do you come neere me now: no worse
man then sir Toby to looke to me. This concurres direct¬≠
ly with the Letter, she sends him on purpose, that I may
appeare stubborne to him: for she incites me to that in
the Letter. Cast thy humble slough sayes she: be oppo¬≠
site with a Kinsman, surly with seruants, let thy tongue
langer with arguments of state, put thy selfe into the
tricke of singularity: and consequently setts downe the
manner how: as a sad face, a reuerend carriage, a slow
tongue, in the habite of some Sir of note, and so foorth.
I haue lymde her, but it is Ioues doing, and Ioue make me
thankefull. And when she went away now, let this Fel¬≠
low be look'd too: Fellow? not Maluolio, nor after my
degree, but Fellow. Why euery thing adheres togither,
that no dramme of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no
obstacle, no incredulous or vnsafe circumstance: What
can be saide? Nothing that can be, can come betweene
me, and the full prospect of my hopes. Well Ioue, not I,
is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

fw.hi: To.
Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Which way is hee in the name of sanctity. If all
the diuels of hell be drawne in little, and Legion himselfe
possest him, yet Ile speake to him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Heere he is, heere he is: how ist with you sir?
How ist with you man?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Go off, I discard you: let me enioy my priuate:
go off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
Mal.
sp.p: Ah ha, does she so?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Go too, go too: peace, peace, wee must deale
gently with him: Let me alone. How do you Maluolio?
How ist with you? What man, defie the diuell: consider,
he's an enemy to mankinde.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you know what you say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
La you, and you speake ill of the diuell, how
he takes it at heart. Pray God he be not bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Carry his water to th'wise woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Marry and it shall be done to morrow morning
if I liue. My Lady would not loose him for more then ile
say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How now mistris?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Lord.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Prethee hold thy peace, this is not the way: Doe
you not see you moue him? Let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
No way but gentlenesse, gently, gently: the Fiend
is rough, and will not be roughly vs'd.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Why how now my bawcock? how dost yu chuck?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I biddy, come with me. What man, tis not for
grauity to play at cherrie‚Äëpit with sathan Hang him foul
Colliar.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get him to say his prayers, good sir Toby gette
him to pray.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My prayers Minx.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No I warrant you, he will not heare of godly¬≠
nesse.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Go hang your selues all: you are ydle shallowe
things, I am not of your element, you shall knowe more
heereafter.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Ist posssible?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
If this were plaid vpon a stage now, I could con¬≠
demne it as an improbable fiction.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
His very genius hath taken the infection of the
deuice man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay pursue him now, least the deuice take ayre,
and taint.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why we shall make him mad indeede.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The house will be the quieter.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come, wee'l haue him in a darke room & bound.
My Neece is already in the beleefe that he's mad: we may
carry it thus for our pleasure, and his pennance, til our ve¬≠
ry pastime tyred out of breath, prompt vs to haue mercy
on him: at which time, we wil bring the deuice to the bar
and crowne thee for a finder of madmen: but see, but see.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: More matter for a May morning.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Heere's the Challenge, reade it: I warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ist so sawcy?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I, ist? I warrant him: do but read.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Giue me.
Youth, whatsoeuer thou art, thou art but a scuruy fellow.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Good, and valiant.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Wonder not, nor admire not in thy minde why I doe call
thee so, for I will shew thee no reason for't.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
A good note, that keepes you from the blow of yÕ§
(Law

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Thou comst to the Lady Oliuia, and in my sight she vses
thee kindly: but thou lyest in thy throat, that is not the matter
I challenge thee for.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Very breefe, and to exceeding good sence‚Äëlesse.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I will way‚Äëlay thee going home, where if it be thy chance
to kill me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Thou kilst me like a rogue and a villaine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Still you keepe o'th windie side of the Law: good.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
Fartheewell, and God haue mercie vpon one of our
soules. He may haue mercie vpon mine, but my hope is better,
and so looke to thy selfe. Thy friend as thou vsest him, & thy
sworne enemie, Andrew Ague‚Äëcheeke.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
If this Letter moue him not, his legges cannot:
Ile giu't him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You may haue verie fit occasion fot't for't : he is now
in some commerce with my Ladie, and will by and by
depart.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Go sir Andrew: scout mee for him at the corner
of the Orchard like a bum‚ÄëBaylie: so soone as euer thou
seest him, draw, and as thou draw'st, sweare horrible: for
t comes to passe oft, that a terrible oath, with a swagge¬≠
ring accent sharpely twang'd off, giues manhoode more
approbation, then euer proofe it selfe would haue earn'd
him. Away.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Nay let me alone for swearing.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Now will not I deliuer his Letter: for the behaui¬≠
our of the yong Gentleman, giues him out to be of good
capacity, and breeding: his employment betweene his
Lord and my Neece, confirmes no lesse. Therefore, this
Letter being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror
in the youth: he will finde it comes from a Clodde‚Äëpole.
But sir, I will deliuer his Challenge by word of mouth;
set vpon Ague‚Äëcheeke a notable report of valor, and driue
the Gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receiue it)
into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, furie, and
impetuositie. This will so fright them both, that they wil
kill one another by the looke, like Cockatrices.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Heere he comes with your Neece, giue them way
till he take leaue, and presently after him.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I wil meditate the while vpon some horrid message
for a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I haue said too much vnto a hart of stone,
And laid mine honour too vnchary on't:
There's something in me that reproues my fault:
But such a head‚Äëstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mockes reproofe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: With the same hauiour that your passion beares,
Goes on my Masters greefes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Heere, weare this Iewell for me, tis my picture:
Refuse it not, it hath no tongue, to vex you:
And I beseech you come againe to morrow.
What shall you aske of me that Ile deny,
That honour (sau'd) may vpon asking giue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Nothing but this, your true loue for my master.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How with mine honor may I giue him that,
Which I haue giuen to you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I will acquit you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Well, come againe to morrow: far‚Äëthee‚Äëwell,
A Fiend like thee might beare my soule to hell.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Gentleman, God saue thee.

fw.hi: Vio.
Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you sir.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
That defence thou hast, betake the too't: of what
nature the wongs are thou hast done him, I knowe not:
but thy intercepter full of despight, bloody as the Hun¬≠
ter, attends thee at the Orchard end: dismount thy tucke,
be yare in thy preparation, for thy assaylant is quick, skil¬≠
full, and deadly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
You mistake sir I am sure, no man hath any quar¬≠
rell to me: my remembrance is very free and cleere from
any image of offence done to any man.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
You'l finde it otherwise I assure you: therefore, if
you hold your life at any price, betake you to your gard:
for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill,
and wrath, can furnish man withall.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I pray you sir what is he?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
He is knight dubb'd with vnhatch'd Rapier, and
on carpet consideration, but he is a diuell in priuate brall,
soules and bodies hath he diuorc'd three, and his incense¬≠
ment at this moment is so implacable, that satisfaction
can be none, but by pangs of death and sepulcher: Hob,
nob, is his word: giu't or take't.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I will returne againe into the house, and desire
some conduct of the Lady. I am no fighter, I haue heard
of some kinde of men, that put quarrells purposely on o¬≠
thers, to taste their valour: belike this is a man of that
quirke.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Sir, no: his indignation deriues it selfe out of a ve¬≠
ry computent iniurie, therefore get you on, and giue him
his desire. Backe you shall not to the house, vnlesse you
vndertake that with me, which with as much safetie you
might answer him: therefore on, or strippe your sword
starke naked: for meddle you must that's certain, or for¬≠
sweare to weare iron about you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
This is as vnciuill as strange. I beseech you doe
me this courteous office, as to know of the Knight what
my offence to him is: it is something of my negligence,
nothing of my purpose.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I will doe so. Signiour Fabian, stay you by this
Gentleman, till my returne.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Pray you sir, do you know of this matter?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I know the knight is incenst against you, euen to
a mortall arbitrement, but nothing of the circumstance
more.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I beseech you what manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nothing of that wonderfull promise to read him
by his forme, as you are like to finde him in the proofe of
his valour. He is indeede sir, the most skilfull, bloudy, &
fatall opposite that you could posssibly haue found in anie
part of Illyria: will you walke towards him, I will make
your peace with him, if I can.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I shall bee much bound to you for't: I am one,
that had rather go with sir Priest, then sir knight: I care
not who knowes so much of my mettle.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Why man hee s a verie diuell, I haue not seen suchThis line has been underlined in pencil.
a firago: I had a passe with him, rapier, scabberd, and all:
and he giues me the stucke in with such a mortall motion
that it is ineuitable: and on the answer, he payes you as
surely, as your feete hits the ground they step on. TheyThis line has been underlined in pencil.
say, he has bin Fencer to the Sophy.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Pox on't, Ile not meddle with him.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
I but he will not now be pacified,
Fabian can scarse hold him yonder.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Plague on't, and I thought he had beene valiant,
and so cunning in Fence, I'de haue seene him damn'd ere
I'de haue challeng'd him. Let him let the matter slip, and
Ile giue him my horse, gray Capilet.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Ile make the motion: stand heere, make a good
shew on't, this shall end without the perdition of soules,
marry Ile ride your horse as well as I ride you.

I haue his horse to take vp the quarrell, I haue perswaded
him the youths a diuell.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
He is as horribly conceited of him: and pants, &
lookes pale, as if a Beare were at his heeles.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
There's no remedie sir, he will fight with you for's
oath sake: marrie hee hath better bethought him of his
quarrell, and hee findes that now scarse to bee worth tal¬≠
king of: therefore draw for the supportance of his vowe,
he protests he will not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Pray God defend me: a little thing would make
me tell them how much I lacke of a man.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Giue ground if you see him furious.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come sir Andrew, there's no remedie, the Gen¬≠
tleman will for his honors sake haue one bowt with you:
he cannot by the Duello auoide it: but hee has promised
me, as he is a Gentleman and a Soldiour, he will not hurt
you. Come on, too't.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Pray God he keepe his oath.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I do assure you tis against my will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Put vp your sword: if this yong Gentleman
Haue done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defie you.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: You sir? Why, what are you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: One sir, that for his loue dares yet do more
Then you haue heard him brag to you he will.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay, if you be an vndertaker, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: O good sir Toby hold: heere come the Officers.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Ile be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Pray sir, put your sword vp if you please.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Marry will I sir: and for that I promis'd you Ile
be as good as my word. Hee will beare you easily, and
raines well.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: This is the man, do thy Office.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.p: Anthonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: You do mistake me sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: No sir, no iot: I know your fauour well:
Though now you haue no sea‚Äëcap on your head:
Take him away, he knowes I know him well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must obey. This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedie, I shall answer it:
What will you do: now my necesssitie
Makes me to aske you for my purse. It greeues mee
Much more, for what I cannot do for you,
Then what befals my selfe: you stand amaz'd,
But be of comfort.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Come sir away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must entreat of you some of that money.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What money sir?
For the fayre kindnesse you haue shew'd me heere,
And part being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my leane and low ability
Ile lend you somehing: my hauing is not much,
Ile make diuision of my present with you:
Hold, there's halfe my Coffer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will you deny me now,
Ist posssible that my deserts to you
Can lacke perswasion. Do not tempt my misery,
Least that it make me so vnsound a man
As to vpbraid you with those kindnesses

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: That I haue done for you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I know of none,
Nor know I you by voyce, or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man,
Then lying, vainnesse, babling drunkennesse,
Or any taint of vice, whose strong corruption
Inhabites our fraile blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh heauens themselues.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: Come sir, I pray you go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l:
Let me speake a little. This youth that you see
(heere,
I snatch'd one halfe out of the iawes of death,
Releeu'd him with such sanctitie of loue;
And to his image, which me thought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I deuotion.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: What's that to vs, the time goes by: Away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But oh, how vilde an idoll proues this God:
Thou hast Sebastian done good feature, shame.
In Nature, there's no blemish but the minde:
None can be call'd deform'd, but the vnkinde.
Vertue is beauty, but the beauteous euill
Are empty trunkes, ore‚Äëflourish'd by the deuill.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: The man growes mad, away with him:
Come, come sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leade me on.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Me thinkes his words do from such passsion flye
That he beleeues himselfe, so do not I:
Proue true imagination, oh proue true,
That I deere brother, be now tane for you.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come hither Knight, come hither Fabian: Weel
whisper ore a couplet or two of most sage sawes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: He nam'd Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet liuing in my glasse: euen such, and so
In fauour was my Brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: Oh if it proue,
Tempests are kinde, and salt waues fresh in loue.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward
then a Hare, his dishonesty appeares, in leauing his frend
heere in necesssity, and denying him: and for his coward¬≠
ship aske Fabian.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
A Coward, a most deuout Coward, religious in
it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Slid Ile after him againe, and beate him.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Do, cuffe him soundly, but neuer draw thy sword

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: And I do not.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Come, let's see the euent.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I dare lay any money, twill be nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Will you make me beleeue, that I am not sent for
you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Go too, go too, thou art a foolish fellow,
Let me be cleere of thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well held out yfaith: No, I do not know you,
nor I am not sent to you by my Lady, to bid you come
speake with her: nor your name is not Master Cesario,
nor this is not my nose neyther: Nothing that is so, is so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
I prethee vent thy folly some‚Äëwhere else, thou
know'st not me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Vent my folly: He has heard that word of some
great man, and now applyes it to a foole. Vent my fol¬≠
ly: I am affraid this great lubber the World will proue a
Cockney: I prethee now vngird thy strangenes, and tell
me what I shall vent to my Lady? Shall I vent to hir that
thou art comming?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
I prethee foolish greeke depart from me, there's
money for thee, if you tarry longer, I shall giue worse
paiment.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth thou hast an open hand: these Wise‚Äë
men that giue fooles money, get themselues a good re¬≠
port, after foureteene yeares purchase.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Now sir, haue I met you again: ther's for you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why there's for thee, and there, and there,
Are all the people mad?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Hold sir, or Ile throw your dagger ore the house.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
This will I tell my Lady straight, I would not be
in some of your coats for two pence.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Come on sir, hold.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Nay let him alone, Ile go another way to worke
with him: Ile haue an action of Battery against him, if
there be any law in Illyria: though I stroke him first, yet
it's no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Let go thy hand.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Come sir, I will not let you go. Come my yong
souldier put vp your yron: you are well flesh'd: Come
on.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will be free from thee. What wouldst yu now?
If thou dar'st tempt me further, draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
What, what? Nay then I must haue an Ounce or
two of this malapert blood from you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Hold Toby, on thy life I charge thee hold.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Will it be euer thus? Vngracious wretch,
Fit for the Mountaines, and the barbarous Caues,
Where manners nere were preach'd: out of my sight.
Be not offended, deere Cesario:
Rudesbey be gone. I prethee gentle friend,
Let thy fayre wisedome, not thy passsion sway
In this vnciuill, and vniust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And heare thou there how many fruitlesse prankes
This Ruffian hath botch'd vp, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this: Thou shalt not choose but goe:
Do not denie, beshrew his soule for mee,
He started one poore heart of mine, in thee.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What rellish is in this? How runs the streame?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dreame:
Let fancie still my sense in Lethe steepe,
If it be thus to dreame, still let me sleepe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Nay come I prethee, would thoud'st be rul'd by me

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O say so, and so be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, I prethee put on this gown, & this beard,
make him beleeue thou art sir Topas the Curate, doe it
quickly. Ile call sir Toby the whilst.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well, Ile put it on, and I will dissemble my selfe
in't, and I would I were the first that euer dissembled in such
Twelfe Night, or, What you will.
in such a gowne. I am not tall enough to become the
function well, nor leane enough to bee thought a good
Studient: but to be said an honest man and a good hous¬≠
keeper goes as fairely, as to say, a carefull man, & a great
scholler. The Competitors enter.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Ioue blesse thee M. Parson.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Bonos dies sir Toby: for as the old hermit of Prage
that neuer saw pen and inke, very wittily sayd to a Neece
of King Gorbodacke, that that is, is: so I being M. Parson,
am M. Parson; for what is that, but that? and is, but is?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: To him sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What hoa, I say, Peace in this prison.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: The knaue counterfets well: a good knaue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Who cals there?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Sir Topas the Curate, who comes to visit Maluo¬≠
lio the Lunaticke.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Topas, sir Topas, good sir Topas goe to my
Ladie.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Out hyperbolicall fiend, how vexest thou this
man? Talkest thou nothing but of Ladies?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Well said M. Parson.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Topas, neuer was man thus wronged, good
sir Topas do not thinke I am mad: they haue layde mee
heere in hideous darknesse.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Fye, thou dishonest sathan: I call thee by the
most modest termes, for I am one of those gentle ones,
that will vse the diuell himselfe with curtesie: sayst thou
that house is darke?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As hell sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why it hath bay Windowes transparant as bari¬≠
cadoes, and the cleere stores toward the South north, are
as lustrous as Ebony: and yet complainest thou of ob¬≠
struction?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I am not mad sir Topas, I say to you this house is
darke,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Madman thou errest: I say there is no darknesse
but ignorance, in which thou art more puzel'd then the
√Ügyptians in their fogge.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I say this house is as darke as Ignorance, thogh
Ignorance were as darke as hell; and I say there was ne¬≠
uer man thus abus'd, I am no more madde then you are,
make the triall of it in any constant question.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning
Wilde‚Äëfowle?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
That the soule of our grandam, might happily
inhabite a bird.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What thinkst thou of his opinion?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I thinke nobly of the soule, and no way aproue
his opinion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Fare thee well: remaine thou still in darkenesse,
thou shalt hold th' opinion of Pythagoras, ere I will allow
of thy wits, and feare to kill a Woodcocke, lest thou dis¬≠
possesse the soule of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir Topas, sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My most exquisite sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay I am for all waters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Thou mightst haue done this without thy berd
and gowne, he sees thee not.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
To him in thine owne voyce, and bring me word
how thou findst him: I would we were well ridde of this
knauery. If he may bee conueniently deliuer'd, I would
he were, for I am now so farre in offence with my Niece,
that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport the vppe¬≠
shot. Come by and by to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Hey Robin, iolly Robin, tell me how thy Lady
does.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Foole.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My Lady is vnkind, perdie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Foole.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alas why is she so?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Foole, I say.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: She loues another. Who calles, ha?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Good foole, as euer thou wilt deserue well at
my hand, helpe me to a Candle, and pen, inke, and paper:
as I am a Gentleman, I will liue to bee thankefull to thee
for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: M. Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I good Foole.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alas sir, how fell you besides your fiue witts?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
Foole, there was neuer man so notoriouslie a¬≠
bus'd: I am as well in my wits (foole) as thou art.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But as well: then you are mad indeede, if you be
no better in your wits then a foole.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
They haue heere propertied me: keepe mee in
darkenesse, send Ministers to me, Asses, and doe all they
can to face me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Aduise you what you say: the Minister is heere.

Maluolio, Maluolio, thy wittes the heauens restore: en¬≠
deauour thy selfe to sleepe, and leaue thy vaine bibble
babble.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Maintaine no words with him good fellow.
Who I sir, not I sir. God buy you good sir Topas: Mar¬≠
ry Amen. I will sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Foole, foole, foole I say.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Alas sir be patient. What say you sir, I am shent
for speaking to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Good foole, helpe me to some light, and some
paper, I tell thee I am as well in my wittes, as any man in
Illyria.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Well‚Äëa‚Äëday, that you were sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
By this hand I am: good foole, some inke, pa¬≠
per, and light: and conuey what I will set downe to my
Lady: it shall aduantage thee more, then euer the bea¬≠
ring of Letter did.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will help you too't. But tel me true, are you not
mad indeed, or do you but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Beleeue me I am not, I tell thee true.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, Ile nere beleeue a madman till I see his brains
I will fetch you light, and paper, and inke.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Foole, Ile requite it in the highest degree:
I prethee be gone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am gone sir, and anon sir,
Ile be with you againe:
In a trice, like to the old vice,
your neede to sustaine.
Who with dagger of lath, in his rage and his wrath,
cries ah ha, to the diuell:
Like a mad lad, paire thy nayles dad,
Adieu good man diuell.
This is the ayre, that is the glorious Sunne,
This pearle she gaue me, I do feel't, and see't,
And though tis wonder that enwraps me thus,

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Yet 'tis not madnesse. Where's Anthonio then,
I could not finde him at the Elephant,
Yet there he was, and there I found this credite,
That he did range the towne to seeke me out,
His councell now might do me golden seruice,
For though my soule disputes well with my sence,
That this may be some error, but no madnesse,
Yet doth this accident and flood of Fortune,
So farre exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am readie to distrust mine eyes,
And wrangle with my reason that perswades me
To any other trust, but that I am mad,
Or else the Ladies mad; yet if 'twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take, and giue backe affayres, and their dispatch,
With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing
As I perceiue she do's: there's something in't
That is deceiueable. But heere the Lady comes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Blame not this haste of mine: if you meane well
Now go with me, and with this holy man
Into the Chantry by: there before him,
And vnderneath that consecrated roofe,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith,
That my most iealious, and too doubtfull soule
May liue at peace. He shall conceale it,
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keepe
According to my birth, what do you say?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ile follow this good man, and go with you,
And hauing sworne truth, euer will be true.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Then lead the way good father, & heauens so shine,
That they may fairely note this acte of mine.

div.head: Actus Quintus. Scena Prima.
[Act 5, Scene 1]

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Now as thou lou'st me, let me see his Letter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Good M. Fabian, grant me another request.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do not desire to see this Letter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This is to giue a dogge, and in recompence desire
my dogge againe.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Belong you to the Lady Oliuia, friends?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I sir, we are some of her trappings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I know thee well: how doest thou my good
Fellow?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truely sir, the better for my foes, and the worse
for my friends.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Iust the contrary: the better for thy friends.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No sir, the worse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry sir, they praise me, and make an asse of me,
now my foes tell me plainly, I am an Asse: so that by my
foes sir, I profit in the knowledge of my selfe, and by my
friends I am abused: so that conclusions to be as kisses, if
your foure negatiues make your two affirmatiues, why
then the worse for my friends, and the better for my foes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Why this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth sir, no: though it please you to be
one of my friends.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Thou shalt not be the worse for me, there's gold.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But that it would be double dealing sir, I would
you could make it another.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O you giue me ill counsell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Put your grace in your pocket sir, for this once,
and let your flesh and blood obey it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
Well, I will be so much a sinner to be a double
dealer: there's another.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play, and the olde
saying is, the third payes for all: the triplex sir, is a good
tripping measure, or the belles of S. Saint Bennet sir, may put
you in minde, one, two, three.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
You can foole no more money out of mee at this
throw: if you will let your Lady know I am here to speak
with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my
bounty further.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry sir, lullaby to your bountie till I come a¬≠
gen. I go sir, but I would not haue you to thinke, that
my desire of hauing is the sinne of couetousnesse: but as
you say sir, let your bounty take a nappe, I will awake it
anon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Here comes the man sir, that did rescue mee.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That face of his I do remember well,
Yet when I saw it last, it was besmear'd
As blacke as Vulcan, in the smoake of warre:
A bawbling Vessell was he Captaine of,
For shallow draught and bulke vnprizable,
With which such scathfull grapple did he make,
With the most noble bottome of our Fleete,
That very enuy, and the tongue of losse
Cride fame and honor on him: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.l: Orsino, this is that Anthonio
That tooke the Phoenix, and her fraught from Candy,
And this is he that did the Tiger boord,
When your yong Nephew Titus lost his legge;
Heere in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In priuate brabble did we apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: He did me kindnesse sir, drew on my side,
But in conclusion put strange speech vpon me,
I know not what 'twas, but distraction.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Notable Pyrate, thou salt‚Äëwater Theefe,
What foolish boldnesse brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou in termes so bloudie, and so deere
Hast made thine enemies?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Orsino: Noble sir,
Be pleas'd that I shake off these names you giue mee:
Anthonio neuer yet was Theefe, or Pyrate,
Though I confesse, on base and ground enough
Orsino's enemie. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingratefull boy there by your side,
From the rude seas enrag'd and foamy mouth
Did I redeeme: a wracke past hope he was:
His life I gaue him, and did thereto adde
My loue without retention, or restraint,
All his in dedication. For his sake,
Did I expose my selfe (pure for his loue)
Into the danger of this aduerse Towne,
Drew to defend him, when he was beset:
Where being apprehended, his false cunning
(Not meaning to partake with me in danger)
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: And grew a twentie yeeres remoued thing
While one would winke: denide me mine owne purse,
Which I had recommended to his vse,
Not halfe an houre before.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: When came he to this Towne?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To day my Lord: and for three months before,
No intrim, not a minutes vacancie,
Both day and night did we keepe companie.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
Heere comes the Countesse, now heauen walkes
on earth:
But for thee fellow, fellow thy words are madnesse,
Three monthes this youth hath tended vpon mee,
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What would my Lord, but that he may not haue,
Wherein Oliuia may seeme seruiceable?
Cesario, you do not keepe promise with me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Madam:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Gracious Oliuia.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What do you say Cesario? Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My Lord would speake, my dutie hushes me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If it be ought to the old tune my Lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine eare
As howling after Musicke.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Still so cruell?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Still so constant Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What to peruersenesse? you vnciuill Ladie
To whose ingrate, and vnauspicious Altars
My soule the faithfull'st offrings haue breath'd out
That ere deuotion tender'd. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Euen what it please my Lord, that shal becom him

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why should I not, (had I the heart to do it)
Like to th'Egyptian theefe, at point of death
Kill what I loue: (a sauage iealousie,
That sometime sauours nobly) but heare me this:
Since you to non‚Äëregardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screwes me from my true place in your fauour:
Liue you the Marble‚Äëbrested Tirant still.
But this your Minion, whom I know you loue,
And whom, by heauen I sweare, I tender deerely,
Him will I teare out of that cruell eye,
Where he sits crowned in his masters spight.
Come boy with me, my thoughts are ripe in mischiefe:
Ile sacrifice the Lambe that I do loue,
To spight a Rauens heart within a Doue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And I most iocund, apt, and willinglie,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would dye.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Where goes Cesario?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: After him I loue,
More then I loue these eyes, more then my life,
More by all mores, then ere I shall loue wife.
If I do feigne, you witnesses aboue
Punish my life, for tainting of my loue.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Aye me detested, how am I beguil'd?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Hast thou forgot thy selfe? Is it so long?
Call forth the holy Father.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, away.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Whether my Lord? Cesario, Husband, stay.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Husband?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I Husband. Can he that deny?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Her husband, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Alas, it is the basenesse of thy feare,
That makes thee strangle thy propriety:
Feare not Cesario, take thy fortunes vp,
Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear'st.
O welcome Father:
Father, I charge thee by thy reuerence
Heere to vnfold, though lately we intended
To keepe in darkenesse, what occasion now
Reueales before 'tis ripe: what thou dost know
Hath newly past, betweene this youth, and me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: A Contract of eternall bond of loue,
Confirm'd by mutuall ioynder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lippes,
Strengthned by enterchangement of your rings,
And all the Ceremonie of this compact
Seal'd in my function, by my testimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my graue
I haue trauail'd but two houres.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O thou dissembling Cub: what wilt thou be
When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickely grow,
That thine owne trip shall be thine ouerthrow:
Farewell, and take her, but direct thy feete,
Where thou, and I (henceforth) may neuer meet.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Lord, I do protest.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O do not sweare,
Hold little faith, though thou hast too much feare.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
For the loue of God a Surgeon, send one pre¬≠
sently to sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
H'as broke my head a‚Äëcrosse, and has giuen Sir
Toby a bloody Coxcombe too: for the loue of God your
helpe, I had rather then forty pound I were at home.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Who has done this sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
The Counts Gentleman, one Cesario: we tooke
him for a Coward, but hee's the verie diuell incardinate.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: My Gentleman Cesario?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Odd's lifelings heere he is: you broke my head
for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do't by sir
Toby.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Why do you speake to me, I neuer hurt you:
You drew your sword vpon me without cause,
But I bespake you faire, and hurt you not.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
If a bloody coxcombe be a hurt, you haue hurt
me: I thinke you set nothing by a bloody Coxecombe.
Heere comes sir Toby halting, you shall heare more: but if
he had not beene in drinke, hee would haue tickel'd you
other gates then he did.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: How now Gentleman? how ist with you?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
That's all one, has hurt me, and there's th'end on't:
Sot, didst see Dicke Surgeon, sot?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O he's drunke sir Toby an houre agone: his eyes
were set at eight i'th morning.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Then he's a Rogue, and a passy measures panyn: I
hate a drunken rogue.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Away with him? Who hath made this hauocke
with them?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Ile helpe you sir Toby, because we'll be drest to¬≠
gether.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p:
Will you helpe an Asse‚Äëhead, and a coxcombe, &
a knaue: a thin fac'd knaue, a gull?

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be look'd too.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I am sorry Madam I haue hurt your kinsman:
But had it beene the brother of my blood,
I must haue done no lesse with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard vpon me, and by that
I do perceiue it hath offended you:
Pardon me (sweet one) euen for the vowes
We made each other, but so late ago.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A naturall Perspectiue, that is, and is not.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Anthonio: O my deere Anthonio,
How haue the houres rack'd, and tortur'd me,
Since I haue lost thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sebastian are you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Fear'st thou that Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How haue you made diuision of your selfe,
An apple cleft in two, is not more twin
Then these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Most wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do I stand there? I neuer had a brother:
Nor can there be that Deity in my nature
Of heere, and euery where. I had a sister,
Whom the blinde waues and surges haue deuour'd:
Of charity, what kinne are you to me?
What Countreyman? What name? What Parentage?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my Father,
Such a Sebastian was my brother too:
So went he suited to his watery tombe:
If spirits can assume both forme and suite,
You come to fright vs.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A spirit I am indeed,
But am in that dimension grossely clad,An ink mark follows the end of this line.
Which from the wombe I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes euen,
I should my teares let fall vpon your cheeke,
And say, thrice welcome drowned Viola.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My father had a moale vpon his brow.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And so had mine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And dide that day when Viola from her birth
Had numbred thirteene yeares.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O that record is liuely in my soule,
He finished indeed his mortall acte
That day that made my sister thirteene yeares.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: If nothing lets to make vs happie both,
But this my masculine vsurp'd attyre:
Do not embrace me, till each circumstance,
Of place, time, fortune, do co‚Äëhere and iumpe
That I am Viola, which to confirme,
Ile bring you to a Captaine in this Towne,
Where lye my maiden weeds: by whose gentle helpe,
I was preseru'd to serue this Noble Count:
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath beene betweene this Lady, and this Lord.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So comes it Lady, you haue beene mistooke:
But Nature to her bias drew in that.
You would haue bin contracted to a Maid,
Nor are you therein (by my life) deceiu'd,
You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd, right noble is his blood:
If this be so, as yet the glasse seemes true,
I shall haue share in this most happy wracke,
Boy, thou hast saide to me a thousand times,
Thou neuer should'st loue woman like to me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And all those sayings, will I ouer sweare,
And all those swearings keepe as true in soule,
As doth that Orbed Continent, the fire,
That seuers day from night.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Giue me thy hand,
And let me see thee in thy womans weedes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: The Captaine that did bring me first on shore
Hath my Maides garments: he vpon some Action
Is now in durance, at Maluolio's suite,
A Gentleman, and follower of my Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He shall inlarge him: fetch Maluolio hither,
And yet alas, now I remember me,
They say poore Gentleman, he's much distract.
sp.stage: Enter Clowne with a Letter, and Fabian.
sp.l: A most extracting frensie of mine owne
From my remembrance, clearly banisht his.
How does he sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p:
Truely Madam, he holds Belzebub at the staues end as
well as a man in his case may do: has heere writ a letter to
you, I should haue giuen't you to day morning. But as a
madmans Epistles are no Gospels, so it skilles not much
when they are deliuer'd.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Open't, and read it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Looke then to be well edified, when the Foole
deliuers the Madman. By the Lord Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: How now, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No Madam, I do but reade madnesse: and your
Ladyship will haue it as it ought to bee, you must allow
Vox.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Prethee reade i'thy right wits.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So I do Madona: but to reade his right wits, is to
reade thus: therefore, perpend my Princesse, and giue
eare.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Read it you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
By the Lord Madam, you wrong me, and
the world shall know it: Though you haue put mee into
darkenesse, and giuen your drunken Cosine rule ouer me,
yet haue I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladie¬≠
ship. I haue your owne letter, that induced mee to the
semblance I put on; with the which I doubt not, but to
do my selfe much right, or you much shame: thinke of
me as you please. I leaue my duty a little vnthought of,
and speake out of my iniury. The madly vs'd Maluolio.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Did he write this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I Madame.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: This sauours not much of distraction.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: See him deliuer'd Fabian, bring him hither:
My Lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
To thinke me as well a sister, as a wife,
One day shall crowne th' alliance on't, so please you,
Heere at my house, and at my proper cost.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Madam, I am most apt t' embrace your offer:
Your Master quits you: and for your seruice done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So farre beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you call'd me Master, for so long:
Heere is my hand, you shall from this time bee
your Masters Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A sister, you are she.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this the Madman?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I my Lord, this same: How now Maluolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Madam, you haue done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Haue I Maluolio? No.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Lady you haue, pray you peruse that Letter.
You must not now denie it is your hand,
Write from it if you can, in hand, or phrase,

fw.hi: Twelfe Night, or, What you will.

sp.l: Or say, tis not your seale, not your inuention:
Y>ou can say none of this. Well, grant it then,
And tell me in the modestie of honor,
Why you haue giuen me such cleare lights of fauour,
Bad me come smiling, and crosse‚Äëgarter'd to you,
So put on yellow stockings, and to frowne
Vpon sir Toby, and the lighter people:
And acting this in an obedient hope,
Why haue you suffer'd me to be imprison'd,
Kept in a darke house, visited by the Priest,
And made the most notorious gecke and gull,
That ere inuention plaid on? Tell me why?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Alas Maluolio, this is not my writing,
Though I confesse much like the Charracter:
But out of question, tis Marias hand.
And now I do bethinke me, it was shee
First told me thou wast mad; then cam'st in smiling,
And in such formes, which heere were presuppos'd
Vpon thee in the Letter: prethee be content,
This practice hath most shrewdly past vpon thee:
But when we know the grounds, and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the Plaintiffe and the Iudge
Of thine owne cause.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Good Madam heare me speake,
And let no quarrell, nor no braule to come,
Taint the condition of this present houre,
Which I haue wondred at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confesse my selfe, and Toby
Set this deuice against Maluolio heere,
Vpon some stubborne and vncourteous parts
We had conceiu'd against him. Maria writ
The Letter, at sir Tobyes great importance,
In recompence whereof, he hath married her:
How with a sportfull malice it was follow'd,
May rather plucke on laughter then reuenge,
If that the iniuries be iustly weigh'd,
That haue on both sides past.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Alas poore Foole, how haue they baffel'd thee?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why some are borne great, some atchieue great¬≠
nesse, and some haue greatnesse throwne vpon them. I
was one sir, in this Enterlude, one sir Topas sir, but that's
all one: By the Lotd Lord Foole, I am not mad: but do you re¬≠
member, Madam, why laugh you at such a barren rascall,
and you smile not he's gag'd: and thus the whirlegigge
of time, brings in his reuenges.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ile be reueng'd on the whole packe of you?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He hath bene most notoriously abus'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Pursue him, and entreate him to a peace:
He hath not told vs of the Captaine yet,
When that is knowne, and golden time conuents
A solemne Combination shall be made
Of our deere soules. Meane time sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario come
(For so you shall be while you are a man:)
But when in other habites you are seene,
Orsino's Mistris, and his fancies Queene.
When that I was and a little tine boy,
with hey, ho, the winde and the raine:
A foolish thing was but a toy,
for the raine it raineth euery day.
But when I came to mans estate,
with hey ho, &c.
Gainst Knaues and Theeues men shut their gate,
for the raine, &c.
But when I came alas to wiue,
with hey ho, &c.
By swaggering could I neuer thriue,
for the raine, &c.
But when I came vnto my beds,
with hey ho, &c.
With tospottes still had drunken heades,
for the raine, &c.
A great while ago the world begon,
hey ho, &c.
But that's all one, our Play is done,
and wee'l striue to please you euery day.
